metadata.name: dc:description
metadata.content: Database of elements and elemental properties (names, symbols, masses, exact masses, van der Waals radii, ionization potential, electron affinity, electronegativity, etc.

atom.scalar: The Greek word for the sun was 'helios'
Boron means 'Bor(ax) + (carb)on'. It is found in borax and behaves a lot like carbon
Named after the city of Magnesia
Named because it was found in Scandinavia
The Titans were giants in Greek mythology
'Vanadis' is another name for the Nordic goddess Freyja
It was discovered near a town named Magnesia in black earth. Thus, it was named 'magnesia nigra', or for short, Manganese.
Named after the German word 'Kobold' for 'goblin'
'Nickel' was the name of a mountain goblin
German 'zinking' for 'rough', because zinc ore is very rough
'Gallia' is an old name for France
Latin 'germania' is an old name for Germany
Named after the small town of Ytterby near Stockholm in Sweden. Terbium. Ytterbium and Gadolinium are also named after this town.
Named after Niobe, the daughter of the Greek god Tantalus.
This name has Greek roots. It means 'like Platinum' - it was difficult to distinguish Molybdenum from Platinum.
Ruthenia is the old name of Russia
Named after 'Indigo' because of its blue spectrum
Arabic 'anthos ammonos' for 'blossom of the god Ammon'
Greek 'lanthanein' for 'hidden'. The Lanthanoids are also called the 'rare earth' elements.
Named after the Greek Prometheus. Prometheus stole the fire from the gods and gave it to mankind.
atom.array: J. A. Marinsky;C. D. Coryell;L. E. Glendenin

atom.scalar: Named after the Finnish chemist Johan Gadolin
Named after the Swedish town of Ytterby
Latin 'holmia' for the old name of Stockholm
Named ofter the Swedish town of Ytterby. Terbium and Ytterbium are also named after this town.
Named after the old name of Scandinavia, 'Thule'.
Like Terbium and Gadolinium, this is named after the Swedish town of Ytterby.
Named after the Roman name 'Lutetia' for Paris
atom.array: Carl F. Auer von Welsbach;G. Urbain

atom.scalar: 'Hafnia' is the old name of Kopenhagen (Denmark)
Named after the Greek myth of Tantalos
'tung sten' means 'heavy stone' in Swedish. The old name (and thus the symbol 'W') was Wolfram, named after a mineral.
Named after the German river Rhine (latin 'Rhenium').
Greek for 'smell'. Its oxides smell strongly like radishes.
Latin 'aurum'. Named after Aurora, the goddess of sunrise
The old name of Bismuth is 'Wismut', which stood for 'white mass'.
Named after Poland to honor Marie Curie

atom.array: D. R. Corson;K. R. McKenzie;E. Segre

atom.scalar: Named after Radium. It ends with 'on' to make it clear that it is a noble gas.
Named after France to honor Marguerite Perey
Latin 'radius' for 'beam', as it is radioactive
Named after the German god of thunder: Thor
Greek 'protos' for 'ancester'. Protactinium is before Actinium in the periodic table.
Greek 'ouranos' for 'heaven'. Named after the planet Uranus.

atom.array: Glenn T. Seaborg;E. M. McMillan;J. W. Kennedy;A.C. Wahl
Glenn T. Seaborg;L. O. Morgan;R. A. James;A. Ghiors
Glenn T. Seaborg;R. A. James;A. Ghiors

atom.scalar: Named after the town Berkeley where it was discovered.
atom.array: Glenn T. Seaborg;A. Ghiors;S. G. Thompson

atom.scalar: Named after the US-State of California.
atom.array: Glenn T. Seaborg;A. Ghiors;S. G. Thompson

atom.scalar: Named after the scientist Albert Einstein.
Named after the scientist Enrico Fermi.
Named after the scientist D.I. Mendeleev.
atom.array: Glenn T. Seaborg;Albert Ghiorso;Bernard Harvey;Gregory Choppin;Stanley G. Thompson

atom.scalar: Named after the scientist Alfred Nobel.
Named after the scientist Ernest Orlando Lawrence.
atom.array: Albert Ghiorso;Torbjorn Sikkeland;Almon Larsh;Robert M. Latimer

atom.scalar: Named after the scientist Ernest Rutherford
Named after the science-town Dubna in Russia
Named after the scientist G. Theodore Seaborg.
Named after the scientist Niels Bohr.
Latin 'hassia' for the German county Hessen. In Hessen a lot elements have been discovered.
Named after the scientist Lise Meitner.
Named after the German city Darmstadt where many elements have been discovered.

atom.scalar: Historically known as eka-mercury. Ununbium is a temporary IUPAC systematic element name.
atom.array: First created at the Gesellschaft f√ºr Schwerionenforschung

atom.scalar: Historically known as eka-thallium. Ununtrium is a temporary IUPAC systematic element name.
atom.array: Russian scientists at Dubna (JINR);American scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

atom.scalar: Historically known as eka-lead. Ununquadium is a temporary IUPAC systematic element name.
Historically known as eka-bismuth. Ununpentium is a temporary IUPAC systematic element name.
atom.array: Russian scientists at Dubna (JINR);American scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.

atom.scalar: Historically known as eka-polonium. Ununhexium is a temporary IUPAC systematic element name.
Temporary symbol and name. Can also be referred to as eka-astatine.
Historically known as eka-radon, eka-emanation before 1960. Ununoctium is a temporary IUPAC systematic element name.
atom.array: Russian scientists at Dubna (JINR);American scientists at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory.
